questions.text: Where are Nissl's granules located within a nerve cell? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Body

 

Explanation:


Nissl's granules are basophilic granular bodies found within the cell body (soma) of neurons. They represent rough endoplasmic reticulum with associated ribosomes that are responsible for protein synthesis in the neuron. These granules are abundant in the cell body where metabolic activity is highest, supporting the neuron's structural and functional needs.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Axon hillock: This is the transitional zone between the cell body and axon where action potentials are initiated. It lacks Nissl substance.
  • Option b. Axons: Axons are specialized for signal conduction, not protein synthesis. They don't contain Nissl granules as this would interfere with their conduction function.
  • Option c. Node of Ranvier: These are gaps in the myelin sheath of myelinated axons that allow for saltatory conduction. They also lack Nissl substance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nissl granules (rough endoplasmic reticulum with ribosomes) are exclusively found in the neuronal cell body, reflecting the compartmentalization of protein synthesis within neurons, with the soma being the primary site for manufacturing cellular components.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man after drinking too much alcohol developed chest pain. X-ray showed pneumomediastinum. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Esophageal perforation

 

Esophageal perforation is a serious condition that can occur spontaneously, often after episodes of severe vomiting or retching, commonly associated with excessive alcohol consumption. This condition can lead to the presence of air in the mediastinum (pneumomediastinum), which can be detected on an X-ray. The classic clinical presentation includes chest pain, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema. When the perforation occurs spontaneously, it is known as Boerhaave syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mallory Weiss syndrome: This condition involves a partial tear at the gastroesophageal junction, usually following severe vomiting. It typically presents with hematemesis (vomiting blood) but does not cause pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Pulsion diverticulum: This type of diverticulum is an outpouching of the esophageal wall due to increased intraluminal pressure. While it can cause dysphagia and regurgitation, it does not typically present with pneumomediastinum.

 

Option D. Acute Pericarditis: Acute pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium and typically presents with sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breathing or lying down. It does not cause pneumomediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esophageal perforation, often associated with severe vomiting and alcohol consumption, can present with chest pain, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema, and is a medical emergency.

questions.text: Kaposi sarcoma present in Which CD4 count? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) <500

 

Kaposi's sarcoma is a common opportunistic infection associated with HIV infection. It typically presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells per cubic millimeter. Kaposi's sarcoma is a type of cancer that forms in the lining of blood and lymph vessels. The exact CD4 count at which Kaposi's sarcoma presents can vary, but it is generally observed in patients with moderately suppressed immune systems, which corresponds to a CD4 count of less than 500 cells/mm³.

 

Graph showing the Opportunistic infections associated with HIV infections and correlation with CD4 T cells counts.

 

 

When the CD4 count is at 500, individuals might also face bacterial skin infections, HSV, and fungal infections. As the CD4 count drops further, other infections like hairy leukoplakia and tuberculosis (at CD4 < 400), PCP, Cryptococcus, and Toxoplasmosis (at CD4 < 200), and infections like MAC, CMV, and lymphoma (at CD4 < 50) can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi's sarcoma in HIV patients generally presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells/mm³.

questions.text: Which form of cutaneous tuberculosis is typically contracted from direct skin inoculation in individuals with good immunity? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis

 

  • Tuberculosis verrusosa cutis (TBVC) is the form of cutaneous tuberculosis that results from direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin of individuals with good immunity. 
  • It is also called "Anatomist's wart" or "Pathologist's wart" because of its occupational association. 
  • TVC presents as an indurated verrucous plaque that develops at the site of inoculation, typically on trauma-prone sites like the extremities. 

 

 

  • Due to the patient's good immunity, this is a paucibacillary form of cutaneous TB where the infection remains localized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scrofuloderma:

 

  • Scrofuloderma is an endogenous form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs through contiguous spread from an underlying tuberculous focus (lymph node, bone, joint) to the overlying skin. 

 

 

  • It is not acquired through direct skin inoculation. 
  • Scrofuloderma is characterized by painless subcutaneous swellings that break down to form discharging sinuses with undermined edges.

 

Option B. Lupus Vulgaris:

 

  • Lupus Vulgaris can occur through both endogenous (hematogenous spread) and, less commonly, exogenous routes, but it typically affects individuals with moderate immunity rather than good immunity. 
  • It presents as a plaque with an active, advancing margin and central scarring. 

 

 

 

  • While it can occasionally be acquired through direct inoculation, it's not the typical presentation in individuals with good immunity, so TBVC is the better option to choose.

 

Option D. Any of the above:

 

  • Only Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis is specifically associated with direct skin inoculation in individuals with good immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis is distinguished as the form of cutaneous TB acquired through exogenous inoculation in individuals with good immunity, presenting as a localized verrucous plaque at trauma-prone sites, particularly on the extremities.

questions.text: Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta from the fetus through? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Umbilical artery

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal circulation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Umbilical vein: Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, not deoxygenated blood.

 

Option C. Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta in fetal circulation, bypassing the lungs. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the IVC, allowing oxygenated blood to bypass the liver. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deoxygenated blood exits the fetus through the umbilical arteries, which return it to the placenta.

 

Ref: Page no 343, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Calculate the median from the given set of observations: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 4, 8. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4.5


The median is the middle value of a data set when arranged in ascending order. For an even number of observations, the median is found by taking the average of the two middle numbers. In this set, the values in ascending order are: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. Since there are 8 values (an even number), the two middle values are 4 and 5. The median is calculated by averaging these two values:

 

Median = (4+5)/2 = 4.5

 

Educational Objective:
 

For an even number of observations, the median is the average of the two middle values when the data set is arranged in ascending order.

questions.text: Which nerve is found within Guyon's canal? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Ulnar nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The ulnar nerve passes through Guyon's canal at the wrist before entering the hand. Compression of the ulnar nerve in this area is known as Guyon canal syndrome. Guyon's canal (also known as the ulnar canal) is a fibro-osseous tunnel at the wrist through which the ulnar nerve and ulnar artery pass. The canal is bounded by the pisiform bone medially, the hook of hamate laterally, and is covered by the volar carpal ligament (a superficial portion of the flexor retinaculum).

 

Other Options:

 

Option b) Radial nerve - The radial nerve does not pass through Guyon's canal. At the wrist level, the superficial branch of the radial nerve passes through the anatomical snuffbox on the lateral aspect of the wrist.

 

Option c) Median nerve - The median nerve passes through the carpal tunnel, not Guyon's canal. The carpal tunnel is located more laterally and is formed by the flexor retinaculum and carpal bones.

 

Option d) Anterior interosseous nerve - This is a branch of the median nerve that runs deep in the forearm and typically terminates before reaching the wrist, so it does not pass through Guyon's canal.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Guyon's canal contains the ulnar nerve and ulnar artery; compression of the ulnar nerve at this site results in Guyon canal syndrome, which presents with motor and/or sensory deficits in the ulnar nerve distribution of the hand.

questions.text: The persistence of ADHD in childhood increases the risk of development of which of the following in adolescence? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder

 

Children with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at an increased risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence. ADHD is characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, which can lead to difficulty in following rules, controlling behavior, and maintaining social norms. When these symptoms persist into adolescence, they can manifest as more serious behavioral problems, such as conduct disorder, characterized by aggressive, antisocial, or defiant behaviors.

 

Conduct disorder is a common progression from ADHD because the underlying impulsivity and lack of self-control associated with ADHD often worsen over time, particularly when untreated. This progression underscores the importance of early intervention in managing ADHD symptoms.

 

Note - Children with ADHD are at risk of developing depression, antisocial personality disorder, substance use disorder, and conduct disorder as adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This disorder involves a consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in other situations, and it is more associated with anxiety disorders rather than ADHD.

 

Option C. Binge eating disorder: This condition involves recurrent episodes of eating large quantities of food, often quickly and to the point of discomfort. It is associated more with emotional regulation issues rather than impulsivity or behavioral problems typical of ADHD.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: This disorder is characterized by excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures. It is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and does not have a direct link to ADHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The persistence of ADHD in childhood significantly increases the risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence, highlighting the need for early and effective management of ADHD symptoms.

questions.text: Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are related to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are specifically used in the staging and prognostication of maxillary sinus carcinoma. Ohngren's line is an imaginary plane drawn from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. This line divides the maxillary sinus into anteroinferior and posterosuperior portions, which has significant prognostic implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebellopontine angle tumor: These tumors are classified using different systems related to their location in the posterior cranial fossa. Ohngren's line has no relevance to cerebellopontine angle tumors, which include acoustic neuromas and meningiomas.

 

Option C. Glomus Jugulare Tumor: These tumors are classified based on their extension from the jugular foramen and involvement of surrounding structures. The Fisch classification system is typically used, not Ohngren's classification.

 

Option D. Basal Cell Carcinoma of eyelid: These tumors are classified according to their histopathological features and TNM staging. Ohngren's line is not used in the classification or prognostication of basal cell carcinomas.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ohngren's line is a critical prognostic indicator in maxillary sinus carcinoma; tumors situated posterosuperior to this line (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those anteroinferior to it (infrastructural) due to their proximity to vital structures.

choices.text: Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile
Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in umbilical artery

questions.text: All are criteria of IUGR except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine A PI < 95%

 

Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) is a condition where a fetus is smaller than expected for the number of weeks of pregnancy. It can result from various factors, including placental insufficiency, maternal health issues, or genetic conditions. Several criteria are commonly used to diagnose IUGR:

 

  • Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a common marker used in the assessment of IUGR. A small abdominal circumference indicates that the fetus might not be growing adequately.
  • Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: Like abdominal circumference, if the estimated fetal weight is below the 3rd percentile, it is a strong indicator of IUGR.
  • Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound that indicates severe placental insufficiency. It is associated with increased risk of adverse perinatal outcomes.

 

However, the option "Uterine A PI < 95%" refers to the uterine artery pulsatility index (PI), which is a measure of the resistance in the uterine artery. In cases of IUGR, resistance is typically high, leading to a high PI, not low. Therefore, a PI < 95% (indicating low resistance) would not be consistent with IUGR. This is why this option is incorrect.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a valid criterion used in the assessment of IUGR.

 

Option B. Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: This criterion is also used in the diagnosis of IUGR.

 

Option C. Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical sign of severe IUGR and is often associated with poor perinatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) is typically high in cases of IUGR due to increased resistance. A low PI (< 95%) would not indicate IUGR, making it the incorrect option in this contex

questions.text: Which of the following is not a food adulteration disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluorosis

 

Fluorosis is not a food adulteration disease. It occurs naturally due to excessive fluoride intake, primarily through drinking water. 

 

Food adulteration diseases are caused by deliberate addition or modification of food items by someone like a shopkeeper for profits.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Aflatoxicosis: Incorrect because it is a food adulteration disease caused by aflatoxin produced by Aspergillus fungus contamination.

 

Option B. Lathyrism: Incorrect because it is a food adulteration disease caused by consumption of Lathyrus sativus (kesari dal) containing the toxin beta-oxalyl aminoalanine (BOAA).

 

Option D. Epidemic dropsy: Incorrect because it is a food adulteration disease caused by mixing of argemone mexicana oil in mustard oil, which leads to generation of the toxin sanguinarine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fluorosis is a natural disease caused by excessive fluoride intake through drinking water and is not a food adulteration disease, unlike aflatoxicosis, lathyrism, and epidemic dropsy which are caused by deliberate food contamination or adulteration.

 

Food Adulteration Disease

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred drug for treatment of post-menopausal breast cancer? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anastrozole

 

Aromatase inhibitors like anastrozole and letrozole are  considered the preferred drugs for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in post-menopausal women whereas tamoxifen is considered drug of choice in pre-menopausal women. Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor whereas tamoxifen works as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), both are effective in blocking the effects of estrogen on breast cancer cells. Methotrexate may be used in breast cancer treatment, however it is not a first line drug. On the other hand, raloxifene is a SERM used for treatment of osteoporosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug used in the treatment of various cancers, including some types of breast cancer. However, it is not typically the first-line choice for post-menopausal breast cancer.

 

Option B. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used for osteoporosis and the prevention of breast cancer, rather than its treatment.

 

Option C. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is a widely used medication for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in both pre-menopausal and post-menopausal women. It is often the preferred choice for breast cancer in pre-menopausal female.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor and is drug of choice for treatment of breast cancer (which is estrogen receptor positive) in post-menopausal females.

questions.text: The classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome includes all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Mental Retardation

 

Explanation: 

 

The classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) consists of cataract, deafness, and congenital heart defects (particularly Patent Ductus Arteriosus). This triad represents the most characteristic manifestations of maternal rubella infection during pregnancy, especially when infection occurs during the first trimester. While mental retardation can occur in children with CRS, it is not part of the classical diagnostic triad but rather an additional manifestation that may be present in severe cases.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cataract - Correct component of the CRS triad. Cataracts are typically bilateral but can be unilateral and develop from damage to the developing lens during embryogenesis.

 

Option B. Deafness - Correct component of the CRS triad. Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common manifestation of CRS, affecting up to 80% of infected infants.

 

Option C. Heart Defects - Correct component of the CRS triad. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common cardiac defect, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis and ventricular septal defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome consists of cataracts, deafness, and congenital heart defects (primarily PDA). Additional manifestations may include microcephaly, mental retardation, purpuric rash ("blueberry muffin" appearance), hepatosplenomegaly, and intrauterine growth restriction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female in late pregnancy presents with seizures and high-grade blood pressure. She is diagnosed with eclampsia and started on magnesium sulfate therapy. As part of her management, certain parameters require close monitoring to prevent magnesium toxicity. Which of the following parameters does not require routine checking during magnesium sulfate therapy in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum magnesium levels

 

Magnesium sulfate is used in the management of eclampsia to prevent and control seizures. However, because magnesium can be toxic at high levels, close monitoring of certain clinical parameters (urine output, deep tendon reflexes and respiratory rate) is essential to avoid complications.

 

Serum magnesium levels, on the other hand, do not require routine monitoring unless there is a clinical suspicion of toxicity based on the above parameters. Routine monitoring of serum magnesium levels is not typically done unless symptoms suggest toxicity, making it the correct answer to this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine output: Essential for monitoring kidney function and preventing magnesium accumulation. Urine output needs to be monitored because decreased kidney function can lead to magnesium accumulation and toxicity. If urine output is less than 25-30 ml/hour (or 100 ml over 4 hours), magnesium sulfate should be withheld.

 

Option B. Deep tendon reflexes: Critical for early detection of magnesium toxicity. A decrease or absence of reflexes indicates that magnesium levels may be too high.

 

Option D. Respiratory rate: Vital for detecting severe toxicity and preventing respiratory arrest. If the respiratory rate drops below 12 breaths per minute, it suggests that magnesium levels are dangerously high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While managing eclampsia with magnesium sulfate, routine monitoring of deep tendon reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate is crucial. Serum magnesium levels are only checked if toxicity is suspected, not as a routine measure.

choices.text: b, d and e only
c and e only
a and c only
Only e is correct

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about drug resistant malaria: (AIIMS May 2019)

 

  1. It is not present in India.
  2. Quinine with clindamycin or doxycycline is still effective treatment.
  3. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective.
  4. Artemether with lumefantrine is useful.
  5. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is not useful due to high risk of recrudescence.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. b, d and e only

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is now the most common cause of malaria as well as most common cause of drug resistant malaria in India (Option a is false)
  • DOC for multiple drug resistant P falciparum is artemisinin compounds, but they are short acting. The short action is responsible for recrudescence when used as monotherapy in malaria. So they are combined with long acting drugs (known as ACT; Artemisinin based Combination Therapy) like 
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North-Eastern states.
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine/Pyrimethamine: DOC all over India except NE states.
  • Artemisinin’s are contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy; but can be given in second and third trimester.
  • So, if drug resistant malaria occurs in 1st trimester of pregnancy, DOC is Quinine. To reduce its toxicity, we commonly add clindamycin (in pregnancy and children) or doxycycline (in other patients).
  • Chloroquine is not effective in drug resistant malaria. So artesunate (not Chloroquine) is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (Option c)  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is not present in India. False. Drug-resistant malaria is present in India. Plasmodium falciparum, known for drug resistance, is a common cause of malaria in India.

 

Option C. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective. False. Chloroquine is not effective in drug-resistant malaria. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug-resistant malaria in India is effectively treated with ACTs like Artemether with lumefantrine. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is avoided due to the risk of recrudescence.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/876-877

choices.text: Wavy fibers
Neutrophils in cardiac muscle
Swelling of cells
Eosinophilic contraction band

questions.text: Histology of reperfused myocardium is suggestive of which of the following features? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eosinophilic contraction band 

 

Light microscopy of reperfused myocardium reveals eosinophilic contraction bands. When blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI, they occur in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes.

 

 

Because the vasculature is injured during the period of ischemia and leaks when flow is restored hence a re-perfused infarct is usually hemorrhagic.

 

Microscopic examination reveals that myocytes that were irreversibly injured during reperfusion frequently have contraction bands, which are intensely eosinophilic intracellular "stripes" composed of closely packed sarcomeres. These are caused by myofibril contractions that are exaggerated when perfusion is restored, exposing the interior of dead cells with damaged plasma membranes to a high concentration of calcium ions from the plasma. Reperfusion thus not only saves reversibly injured cells but also changes the morphology of lethally injured cells.

 

Because of impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemma damage, intracellular calcium levels rise during ischemia. After reperfusion, this causes augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wavy fibers:

 

  • Description: Wavy fibers are an early histologic change seen in myocardial infarction, indicating stretching of non-contracting fibers.
  • Timing: These are seen in the early stages of ischemic injury before reperfusion.

 

Option B. Neutrophils in cardiac muscle:

 

  • Description: Neutrophil infiltration is a typical feature of the inflammatory response that occurs a few hours to days after myocardial infarction.
  • Timing: These are seen in the subsequent inflammatory phase following ischemic injury and are not specific to reperfusion injury.

 

Option C. Swelling of cells:

 

  • Description: Cellular swelling is a sign of reversible injury and occurs early in the ischemic process due to the failure of ion pumps.
  • Timing: This occurs before the irreversible injury and reperfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosinophilic contraction bands are a characteristic histological feature of reperfused myocardium, indicating irreversible injury and exaggerated myofibril contraction due to high intracellular calcium levels upon restoration of blood flow.

questions.text: The imaging shows a detailed cross-sectional view of the esophageal wall and surrounding structures. What is the primary use of this imaging modality? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staging of esophageal cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is primarily used for staging esophageal cancer, particularly for T (tumor) and N (nodal) staging. Its high-resolution imaging capabilities allow detailed visualization of the esophageal wall layers and surrounding lymph nodes. However, for M (metastasis) staging, PET-CT remains the investigation of choice, as is true for most cancers.

 

Additional uses of EUS include:

 

  • Assessment of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, particularly gastrinomas in the duodenum
  • Evaluation of biliary microlithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identifying the cause of dysphagia: While EUS can visualize esophageal structures, it's not the primary tool for diagnosing causes of dysphagia. Standard endoscopy and barium studies are more commonly used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Assessing cardiac and aortic pathology: This is done using transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), which is a different procedure where the ultrasound probe faces anteriorly to examine the heart, rather than examining the esophageal wall itself.

 

Option D. Evaluation of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): 24-hour pH monitoring is the standard test for GERD evaluation. EUS is not routinely used for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ultrasound is the investigation of choice for T and N staging of esophageal cancer, while PET-CT is used for M staging.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine

 

The question asks which of the listed options is not a neurotransmitter derived from amino acids. To answer this, let's break down each of the options:

 

  • Dopamine is a well-known neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine. Tyrosine is first converted to DOPA, which then converts to dopamine. Dopamine plays various roles in the brain, including involvement in reward, motivation, and the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.
  • Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Tryptophan is converted into 5-hydroxytryptophan, which is then decarboxylated to form serotonin. Serotonin is involved in mood regulation, sleep, and other functions.
  • GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate. The conversion of glutamate to GABA involves a decarboxylation reaction that requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor. GABA plays a crucial role in reducing neuronal excitability throughout the nervous system.
  • Creatine, however, is not a neurotransmitter. While creatine is synthesized from the amino acids glycine, arginine, and methionine, it functions primarily as a molecule that helps to supply energy to cells, particularly muscle cells, by regenerating ATP (adenosine triphosphate). Creatine is not involved in neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine.

 

Option B. Serotonin: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tryptophan.

 

Option C. GABA: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatine is not a neurotransmitter. It is a molecule that plays a key role in energy metabolism, particularly in muscle cells, but it does not function in neurotransmission. Dopamine, serotonin, and GABA, on the other hand, are all neurotransmitters derived from amino acids.

choices.text: A patient who is in acute crisis
A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning
A patient with strong ego and high motivation

questions.text: In which of the following patients, supportive psychotherapy would not be preferred? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A patient with strong ego and high motivation

 

A patient with strong ego and high motivation: Advanced psychoanalysis are advised due to the patient's capacity for deep psychological work. Supportive psychotherapy, which focuses on immediate coping, is considered less effective for this patient.

 

Supportive psychotherapy is aimed at supporting the patient through reassurance, guidance, and a therapeutic relationship without delving deeply into their past or cognitive processes. It is particularly useful for patients in acute crisis, those with cognitive deficits, and severely ill patients with deficient ego functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient who is in acute crisis: Supportive psychotherapy is highly appropriate as it focuses on providing immediate support and reassurance without exploring complex underlying issues.

 

Option B. A patient with cognitive deficits: These patients may struggle to understand more intricate forms of psychotherapy, making supportive psychotherapy a suitable option to provide essential support and stabilization.

 

Option C. A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning: These patients often have low frustration tolerance and cannot handle the complexities of other forms of therapy, making supportive psychotherapy beneficial to provide stability and support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supportive psychotherapy is not preferred for patients with a strong ego and high motivation, as they can handle and benefit from more complex and deeper forms of therapy.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lateral medullary syndrome

 

The patient's presentation with loss of pain and temperature sensation from the left side of the face and the right side of the body, along with dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex, suggests involvement of the lateral medulla. Additionally, the presence of Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) on the left side further supports this diagnosis.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). The key clinical features include:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face due to involvement of the spinal trigeminal nucleus.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysarthria and dysphagia due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (cranial nerves IX and X).
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome due to disruption of the descending sympathetic pathways.
  • Ataxia due to involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral pontine syndrome: Lateral pontine syndrome involves the pons and typically affects cranial nerves that are not involved in this patient's presentation. For example, it often involves the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), leading to facial weakness, which is not described in this case.

 

Option B. Medial medullary syndrome: Medial medullary syndrome affects the medial structures of the medulla, including the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), and results in ipsilateral tongue weakness and contralateral hemiparesis. This does not match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Locked-In Syndrome: Locked-In Syndrome results from bilateral lesions in the ventral pons, leading to quadriplegia and anarthria, but with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. The patient's symptoms do not align with this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is characterized by ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby presented with the following symptoms. What is the ideal treatment for the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate surgery

 

The image shows a 2-month-old baby with leukocoria, which refers to a white reflection in the pupil. The differential diagnoses for a 2-month-old presenting with leukocoria include congenital cataract and congenital glaucoma. In both cases, surgery is the definitive treatment.

 

Congenital cataract is more likely in this scenario as the whiteness is confined to the pupil, whereas congenital glaucoma typically causes the entire cornea to appear hazy.

 

 

 

In both the condition, Immediate surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications like stimulus deprivation amblyopia, which can lead to permanent vision impairment if treatment is delayed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. First try medical management: Medical management is primarily used to manage congenital glaucoma temporarily until surgery can be performed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, immediate surgery is necessary.

 

Option C. Surgery after 2 years: Delaying surgery to 2 years increases the risk of amblyopia, a condition where the brain starts ignoring signals from the affected eye, leading to vision loss.

 

Option D. Surgery after 6 months of age: Postponing surgery to 6 months also poses a high risk of developing amblyopia, as early surgical intervention is critical to ensure normal visual development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 2-month-old presenting with leukocoria, immediate surgery is the ideal treatment to prevent amblyopia and ensure proper visual development.

questions.text: The active site of enzyme is complimentary to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substrate

 

The active site of an enzyme is complementary to the substrate. The active site is a specific region of the enzyme where the substrate binds, forming an enzyme-substrate complex. This binding is highly specific and is often likened to a lock-and-key or induced-fit model. It provides a specific environment that facilitates the conversion of substrate into product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition state: The transition state refers to the intermediate state of a substrate as it undergoes a reaction and transforms into a product. While enzymes stabilize the transition state during catalysis, the active site itself is typically complementary to the substrate, not the transition state.

 

Option B. Allosteric activator: Allosteric activators bind to allosteric sites on enzymes, which are distinct from the active site. Allosteric regulation involves a change in the enzyme's conformation, affecting its activity.

 

Option D. Product: The active site is not complementary to the product. Once the reaction occurs, the product is released from the active site, allowing the enzyme to participate in another catalytic cycle with a new substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of the active site of an enzyme and its relationship to substrates. The active site of an enzyme is complimentary to the substrate, allowing specific interactions that enable the enzyme to catalyze a particular chemical reaction. It stabilizes the transition state of the reaction, facilitating the conversion of substrates into products.

choices.text: Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of drug dependence? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Use of illegal substances

 

Explanation: 

 

Use of illegal substances is not a diagnostic feature of drug dependence. Drug dependence is defined by specific psychological and physiological features related to substance use patterns and their effects, regardless of whether the substance is legal or illegal. Dependence can develop to legal substances (such as alcohol, prescription medications) just as it can to illegal substances.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Tolerance (Incorrect): Tolerance is a core feature of drug dependence, defined as "increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect." As the body adapts to the presence of the substance, more is needed to achieve the same psychoactive effects, which is a hallmark sign of dependence.
  • Option B. Persistent desire to quit drug (Incorrect): A persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use is a recognized feature of dependence. This represents the loss of control aspect of addiction, where individuals recognize the problems caused by their substance use but struggle to stop despite their intentions.
  • Option C. Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period (Incorrect): Taking the substance in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended is a characteristic feature of dependence. This reflects the impaired control over substance use that defines dependence.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dependence is characterised by a strong drive to use the substance, as manifested by 

  1. Tolerance- Increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect 
  2. Withdrawal symptoms: Typical symptoms that develop when the substance intake is reduced or stopped.
  3. Craving- Strong desire or urge to use the substance
  4. Inability to control substance taking behaviour in terms of its onset, termination or levels of use.
  5. Continued use of a substance despite clear harmful consequences.
  6. Progressive neglect of other interests because of substance use.

questions.text: A tourist group was headed by a tour guide. They were seen many times in an area. Which kind of group dynamics does this represent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herd

 

A herd is a group of people with a leader whom they follow without questioning - like a political party leader being followed by party workers. In this case, the tourist group follows their tour guide without questioning, making it a classic example of herd behavior.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Crowd: Incorrect because a crowd is a temporary gathering of people who come together due to common interest without any leader or organization, like people gathering to watch a cricket match.

 

Option B. Band: Incorrect because a band is a community comprised of groups of families who not only live together but follow a certain pattern of life and culture.

 

Option D. Mob: Incorrect because while a mob has a leader, it is highly emotional, unstable, disorganized and sometimes acts against the law.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. SGLT2 inhibitors work by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine. This mechanism of action results in a higher concentration of glucose in the urinary tract, which can promote bacterial growth and lead to an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity but is not associated with an increased risk of UTIs. Instead, it can cause side effects such as fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor that increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels in the bloodstream. It is associated with risks such as pancreatitis and gastrointestinal disturbances but not with an increased risk of UTIs.

 

Option D. Metformin: This is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. Common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., diarrhea) and vitamin B12 deficiency, but it does not increase the risk of UTIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This highlights the importance of monitoring for UTIs in patients prescribed this medication.
